data.title: It's impossible to change physic mode for instanced/inherited physic objects
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
If you create a scene with physic object node as a root, and then you instance it, you will be unable to change physic mode in this instanced scene: 
![instancedbodiesproperties](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/17830971/3cf50092-66dd-11e6-9d2f-d8b7e65514e2.gif)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a scene with a rigid body as a root.
2. Instance this scene and change physic mode
3. (optionally) Inherit scene from 1 and change physic mode, then instance it.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[InstancedPhysicPropertyNotUpdated.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/428261/InstancedPhysicPropertyNotUpdated.zip)

data.title: Ability to change node type of inherited scene
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I think it would make sense if we could change node type of base scene, just like we can with regular nodes. For example I quite often have base scene which is a `Spatial` and I often need to inherit it and make it a `Body`. Currently this is not possible and every workaround for this problem have it's own disadvantages.  
I think it would be great if instanced scenes could also benefit from this change and also have the ability to change it's base node type

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Multi-line String creates duplicate string
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** 2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Alright folks, this is a pretty fascinating bug: 

```
    get_node("RichTextLabel").set_bbcode("""
    hello
    """)
```

This is valid `GDScript` syntax, but, it will actually insert 2x `hello` strings instead of just one.

If you do it without a initial line break:

```
    get_node("RichTextLabel").set_bbcode("""hello
    """)
```

It works fine.  I am making some extensive tooltips and need the line breaks but it literally duplicated my text, lol pretty funny tbh. I am not sure if this intended :P

data.title: Right click on an instance / object in the Scene tree and "Copy path" to then paste in script editor
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Any OS

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I'm regularly finding reference to instances using get_node("").  I would love to be able to right click on an instance in my scene tree and "copy path" so I can paste it into the script editor without having to work it out in my head.  It would speed up the workflow and reduce errors.

data.title: Doc: older UI in “Learning step by step” [enhancement]
data.body: The [“learning step by step”](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/tutorials/step_by_step/_step_by_step.html) pages are great but some parts use older versions of Godot: - older version of scene inspector in [Instancing, step by step](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/tutorials/step_by_step/instancing.html#instancing-step-by-step) (I had to click the button with a link icon, instead of "plus", which now adds a node) →  - .scn instead of .tscn scene in [Instancing](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/tutorials/step_by_step/instancing.html) and [Scripting](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/tutorials/step_by_step/scripting.html) If it may be useful, I can extend this list, as I'm going through these tutorials right now. Thanks a lot for your work! [Edit: typo]

data.title: Wrong UV mapping when atlasing enabled for 3D objects
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1, Win 10 x64

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Atlas generation plays bad with `GridMap`/`MeshLibrary`: the atlas is generated according to the settings in image groups and the meshes have it assigned instead of the original textures, but the UV mapping is wrong so the whole atlas image is mapped instead of the relevant region.
**UPDATE:** It looks as though atlasing doesn't work at all for 3D. Whilst I detected the issue with grid maps, I found it also breaks imported scenes.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a `MeshLibrary` with at least two meshes with different textures.
2. Create a `GridMap` making use of both meshes.
3. Add all textures to a texture group and enable atlas generation.
4. Run the game.

data.title: Import Mesh - Normals option sometimes doesn't work.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Windows, G2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

The checkbox for Normals in import mesh behaves a bit quirky.

I started an import of a set of meshes, and didn't check the Normal option.  I of course didn't get any lightning, and I chose to reimport, and checked the option.  It worked for the first, however, when I went to reimport the other meshes with the same missing option, the dialog remembers my selection, and the option appears checked, but must not be capturing it.  As I have to uncheck and recheck it for it to import with Normals.  Otherwise it will not work, even though the option is now checked by default.

data.title: [3D Mode] Viewmodel/Viewhud Layering
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot Version 3.0 -  All operating system versions

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

(Note: This is inspired by looking into older FPS games and analyzing how "viewmodels" work.)

First of all, viewmodels are objects placed in a separate viewing space that doesn't exist or interact with the world the player/avatar is located, while still recieving light and shadow information without sacrifice.

Second, I've been taking a good look at some examples of First Person Shooter/First Person scenarios using the Godot Engine, and what I have noticed is that objects are rendered in front but within the camera while both are within a 3D hitbox or physical collision body to prevent objects from clipping/phasing through objects. Is there a way to add a function to the 3D Camera Node to create an array of separate 3D viewing layers to import and place the 3D objects within? Without sacrificing light and shadow detail?

This may have been an advanced suggestion to ask as a feature, but it would be useful for creating 3D Heads Up Display GUI in one 3d viewing layer and the arms/limbs holding a weapon or object in another separate layer. Hope this explanation wasn't too confusing to understand.

Basically, would it be possible to add a feature for specifying custom tooltip texts in exported variables?
The main motivation is to improve communication between team members inside a game project, particularly between those that produce development tools and those that use them.

---

Thanks in advance!

data.title: [2.x] Allowing *Player.play/set_stream to return ERR_FILE_UNRECOGNIZED etc.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
OS is N/A.
Godot 2.2 Alpha (Git)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
If supplying one of the stream node play functions (and probably other related nodes/functions like set_stream) a file that is invalid for it to play back, it reports on the debugger that it is ERR_FILE_UNRECOGNIZED. It does not, however, actually return this value to the application itself.

It would be nice if the set_stream/play and related functions (for example, StreamPlayer.play) could also return this and other appropriate ERR_ values so that any calling function/node could respond accordingly - for example, a music player application could remove the offending file from its playlists.

data.title: Automatic keys mode for Animation Player
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Any device and Version

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Now we have to press key icon each time we animate something. If you forget to do it, engine clear the value and replace it with the previous. In simple game it cause 100s of extra actions. In more complex games it is 1000s of pointless extra clicks (more than 3000 in my case). Godot animation player need auto key mode, when you change any value and it set a key automatically and rewrite it, when value changed again.

It will be faster and easier, like in any other engine.

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Introduce callback function to custom modules
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 x64 - Godot 2.1 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
During talks on IRC about how a custom module can register itself with the main loop in order for it to handle process notifications by itself, there was still the issue as to how the module could self-initialize itself.

The registering part would be solved by this call:
`OS::get_singleton()->get_main_loop()->connect("idle_frame",this,"mystep")`

@reduz proposed an idea that a callback could be introduced which would call every module when the main loop is created and when it's removed, which would effectively solve the issue of signaling a module that it should initialize itself.

data.title: Suggestion : Curve2D.get_normal()
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1 stable official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I had to find the normal of a point on a Curve2D but there is no built-in function to do so.
Then i suggest to implement this function in the next release.
This would be very useful for low-math-level-users like me :)
Thanks a lot.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
Here is the function i made for this task :
http://pastebin.com/RQ2vZU2q

```
func get_normal(idx, fraction, precision):
    var previous_point = mycurve.interpolate(idx, fraction - precision)
    var next_point = mycurve.interpolate(idx, fraction + precision)
    var normal = (next_point - previous_point).normalized().rotated(PI/2)
    return normal.angle()
```

Cubemap is wrong saved when scene is closed and open again

data.title: 'Drag and Drop' and 'Clear' are not functional in Cubemap creation.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 - Godot 2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When creating a Cubemap resource, you can not drag and drop textures onto the appropriate slot in the editor. It seems that trying to clear the texture slot does not work properly either.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a WorldEnvironment Node **->** Create a new Environment **->** Create a new Cubemap in said Environment **->**  Attempt to drag textures onto appropriate 'Side' slots **->** Fail miserably **->** Sigh deeply as you now have to spend 20 precious seconds of your life manually loading the six textures.

data.title: Implemented UndoRedo mergeable modes
data.body:
This patch adds a enum for the undo redo mergeable mode(together with a third mode `MERGE_ALL`), and makes the mergeable mode fully functional.

The behavior of each mode is:
- `MERGE_DISABLE`: When enabled, all `do`/`undo` operations stay in separate actions.
- `MERGE_ENDS`: When enabled, the action `do` operation is from the first action one created and the `undo` operation is from the last subsequent action with the same name.
- `MERGE_ALL`: When  enabled, the `do`/`undo` operations in a set of subsequent actions, with the same name, are merged into one. 

Closes #4061, and possibly several others UndoRedo related issues.

data.title: Added add_property_info function to Globals and EditorSettings classes
data.body: This make possible add custom hints to `Globals`/`EditorSettings` properties(file paths, enums, bit flags, etc...).
